# Banking system stable

Despite increased uncertainty in the global economy and financial markets, the Hong Kong banking system remained stable in 2018. The effectiveness of liquidity and credit risk management systems of authorized institutions continued to be a key regulatory focus for the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) throughout the year. Given the continued rise in cyber threats and the broader adoption of fintech in the banking sector, the HKMA strengthened regulatory oversight on technology risk management and business continuity capabilities of authorized institutions. In May, the HKMA issued the revised guidelines on the authorization of virtual banks and began processing applications for virtual bank authorization. In terms of conduct regulation, the HKMA took further measures to enhance regulatory oversight of sales practices for investment and insurance products by authorized institutions, promote accessible banking services for disabled individuals, and foster a customer-centric corporate culture.

As financial crimes become more complex and globalized, the HKMA continues to leverage new technologies and risk-based approaches to enhance Hong Kong's capacity to combat money laundering and terrorist financing. The HKMA has made commendable progress in implementing international regulatory standards in Hong Kong, including capital adequacy standards, disclosure standards, liquidity standards, and large risk exposure limits. In addition, the HKMA has strengthened communication with the banking sector to ensure an appropriate balance between regulatory effectiveness and market development.

At the same time, the HKMA continues to ensure that Hong Kong has a credible resolution mechanism for authorized institutions, which includes introducing rules on minimum loss-absorbing capacity requirements to address a major obstacle in the feasibility of resolving authorized institutions.

# Goal

One of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's overall objectives is to promote the safety and stability of the banking system. To achieve this goal, it relies on establishing and maintaining a financial system with high resilience that can provide the essential financial services required by the Hong Kong economy.

Banks may affect the stability of the banking system due to their operational practices, or even in extreme cases, due to an unorderly collapse. As a regulatory authority, the Financial Services and Treasury Bureau plays a crucial role in ensuring financial stability by ensuring banks have the capacity to withstand shocks, respond to crises, and recover to normal operations, ultimately helping to prevent collapses. The Financial Services and Treasury Bureau is responsible for prudentially supervising banks and licensing authorized institutions in Hong Kong, including licensed banks, restricted-license banks, and deposit-taking companies. It also oversees the designation and regulation of certain financial market infrastructures.

However, the Financial Secretary cannot guarantee that the financial system is entirely risk-free, and Hong Kong's prudential regulatory system is not designed to ensure "zero risk." As one of the resolution mechanism authorities, the Financial Secretary aims to ensure that, once an authorized institution is no longer viable, its orderly resolution can be carried out. To this end, Hong Kong has established a financial institution resolution mechanism, under which the Financial Secretary serves as the resolution authority for a number of financial institutions, including authorized institutions. To establish an efficient Hong Kong resolution mechanism, it is necessary to formulate resolution legislation and policy standards, conduct resolution planning to remove obstacles to the feasibility of resolving authorized institutions, and build the operational capacity of the HKMA to resolve non-viable authorized institutions. To effectively carry out the aforementioned tasks, the HKMA needs to adopt approaches that are consistent with and coordinated internationally.

# 2018 in Review

# Overview of Regulatory Work

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority conducted 187 off-site inspections in 2018, covering a wide range of areas including the CAMEL ratings of authorized institutions, corporate governance, business operations, risk management, and the business strategies of authorized institutions in responding to the development of fintech. To further enhance the risk governance level of authorized institutions, the HKMA held 27 meetings with the boards of authorized institutions or committees under the boards, and followed up on the progress of authorized institutions in implementing corporate governance guidelines. In addition, the HKMA held 28 three-way meetings with authorized institutions and their external auditors.

In addition to off-site reviews, the HKMA continued to conduct regular on-site inspections and complement them with thematic assessments to examine areas assessed as higher risk. During the year, the HKMA conducted a total of 392 on-site inspections and thematic assessments, continuing to focus primarily on credit risk management in its reviews and assessments. Other key areas included technology risk and business operation risk management, as well as measures to combat money laundering and terrorist financing. The HKMA also increased the number of on-site inspections and thematic assessments targeting liquidity and market risk management, as well as the implementation of the Basel Capital Adequacy Framework. Special review teams also conducted on-site inspections of authorized institutions' securities, investment products, insurance, and Mandatory Provident Fund (MPF) related businesses.

Table 1 contains a summary of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's regulatory work in 2018.

# Credit Risk Regulation

# Credit Growth and Asset Quality

Credit growth slowed in 2018, with the total loan amount increasing by 4.4% for the year, compared to a 16.1% increase in 2017 (Table 2). Trade financing decreased by 7.6% in 2018. The slowdown in loan growth was mainly due to the increasingly uncertain global economic and trade environment, leading to a contraction in credit demand.

Table 2: Growth in Loans and Advances

The total amount of related loans in the mainland increased by 1.4% to 42,490 billion HK dollars at the end of 2018, lower than the growth rate in 2017 (Table 3).

Table 3: Domestic Loan Growth

The asset quality of accredited institutions remained stable in 2018. The specific classified loan ratio for retail banks decreased from 0.56% at the end of 2017 to 0.50% at the end of 2018, far below the long-term average of 2.1% since 2000; during the same period, the specific classified loan ratio for the overall banking sector decreased from 0.68% to 0.55%. Regarding mainland-related loans, the specific classified loan ratio for retail banks decreased from 0.75% to 0.63% in 2018, while the relevant ratio for the overall banking sector also decreased from 0.67% a year earlier to 0.54%.

Within the year, the HKMA will strengthen its supervision to ensure that authorized institutions continue to adopt prudent credit risk management standards. In particular, the HKMA will proactively understand the background and structure of large enterprises, thereby enhancing the corporate credit risk monitoring system. In addition, the HKMA will conduct specialized assessments focusing on key credit risk management monitoring measures, such as approval criteria and risk management for large enterprise loans, loan classification and provisioning systems, credit risk governance frameworks, risk management for property developers' loans, and secured loans and policy collateral loans.

# Property Mortgage Loan

Residential property prices reached a historical high in July 2018 but showed signs of easing in the second half of the year. The eight rounds of countercyclical macroprudential measures introduced by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) since October 2009 have enhanced the Hong Kong banking system's ability to withstand potential reversals in the local property market. The average mortgage loan-to-value ratio for new residential mortgages dropped from 64% in September 2009, before the HKMA introduced its first round of countercyclical measures, to 46% in December 2018. The average debt service-to-income ratio also fell from 41% in August 2010, when the relevant ratio cap was first introduced, to 34% in December 2018 (Figure 1).

Figure 1: Average Mortgage Loan-to-Value Ratio and Repayment-to-Income Ratio for Newly Issued Residential Mortgage Loans

# Regulation of Business Operations and Technological Risks

The technology risks faced by the banking industry remain relatively high. In 2016, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) introduced the "Cyber Defense Assessment Framework." Phase One implementation plan covered 30 authorized institutions, including all major banks, which have completed three stages of assessment: self-risk assessment, maturity assessment, and (if applicable) risk information-led cyber attack and defense simulation tests. These assessments have helped authorized institutions identify areas requiring improvement and take remedial measures to strengthen their cyber defense. Meanwhile, the HKMA has developed a timeline for Phases Two and Three implementation plans, which will cover the remaining authorized institutions. This year, the HKMA conducted on-site inspections, focusing on reviewing the cybersecurity control measures, outsourcing arrangements, and information technology governance of authorized institutions.

# Wisdom Bank

The HKMA continues to collaborate with the banking industry on the seven measures introduced in September 2017 to promote smart banking, aiming to foster the development of fintech in Hong Kong. On the regulatory front, the HKMA issued revised guidelines on the recognition of virtual banks in May. Additionally, under the "Banking Easy" initiative, the HKMA has simplified regulatory requirements related to remote account opening, online loans, and online wealth management. These optimized regulatory requirements help banks provide better online banking user experiences. In September, the scope of the "Banking Easy" initiative was expanded to promote the adoption of financial compliance technology (Regtech) by banks. The three new focuses include monitoring technology for combating money laundering and terrorist financing, Regtech for prudential risk management and compliance, and machine-readable regulatory requirements.

Mr. Man Kuet Hung, Deputy Governor of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, delivered a speech titled "Financial Compliance Technology in the New Era of Smart Banking" at the "Hong Kong Bankers' Summit 2018" hosted by the Hong Kong Bankers' Association.

# Regulation of Liquidity and Market Risk

As the US monetary policy continues to normalize, the HKMA has strengthened supervision of liquidity risks to ensure that authorized institutions prudently and effectively manage their liquidity risks. This year, the HKMA conducted a round of thematic assessments to evaluate the preparedness of authorized institutions for the possible tightening of dollar liquidity and their ability to conduct internal liquidity stress tests. In addition, the HKMA monitored compliance by authorized institutions with the "Net Stable Funding Ratio" requirement that took effect in January.

The HKMA, in addition to reviewing market risk management of authorized institutions' bond portfolios, conducted a special on-site review of the Global Foreign Exchange Code and margin and risk mitigation standards for non-central clearing OTC derivatives to examine the extent to which authorized institutions adhere to new international standards in their treasury operations.

# Combat Money Laundering and Terrorist Fundraising

The Risk Assessment Report on Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing in Hong Kong, published in April, points out that Hong Kong's banking system faces high money laundering threats, similar to other international financial centers, reflecting the increasing globalization and complexity of financial services. The money laundering threats facing Hong Kong not only originate from local criminal activities but, to a greater extent, from overseas activities. These overseas activities include illegal proceeds from corruption abroad, fraudulent activities by transnational criminal organizations, tax evasion, and risks related to sanctions due to Hong Kong's status as a payment and trade hub. With the assistance of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, the government has formulated a Policy Statement on Combating Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing, which outlines responses to these threats. The objective is to enhance the capacity to combat money laundering and terrorist financing while also attracting and facilitating legitimate businesses.

The 2018 Amendment to the Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorist Financing (Financial Institutions) Ordinance took effect on March 1, introducing revisions that grant flexibility in verifying customer identities to align with the development of recognized institutions utilizing technology to facilitate customer account openings. The new legislation also expanded the scope of application, requiring lawyers, accountants, real estate agents, and trust or company service providers to take responsibility for combating money laundering and terrorist financing, thereby comprehensively strengthening the anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing regime. These revisions, together with amendments to the Companies Ordinance aimed at enhancing transparency of beneficial ownership, assist recognized institutions in carrying out their work against money laundering and terrorist financing.

To strengthen and further enhance communication with authorized institutions on the regulatory approaches and policies of combating money laundering and terrorist financing, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority issued in October a new section titled "Regulatory Approach to Combating Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing" under the Regulatory Policy Manual, as well as the revised "Guidelines on Combating Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing (Applicable to Authorized Institutions)" in conjunction with relevant legal amendments. This aims to more effectively implement a risk-based approach and reduce obstacles for authorized institutions in adopting new technologies to combat money laundering and terrorist financing.

The role of information exchange in combating money laundering and terrorist financing systems is becoming increasingly important. Under the support of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Hong Kong Bankers' Association (Banking Association), the banking sector actively participates in the Anti-Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing Intelligence Working Group (Intelligence Working Group) and has already achieved substantive results. The review of the pilot program related to the Intelligence Working Group was initiated at the end of 2018 and will be completed in early 2019.

# 香港的國際金融中心地位

鞏固香港的國際金融中心地位是金管局主要職責之一。旨在促進銀行及支付業界開發與應用金融科技的7項措施，於年內取得良好進展，最佳例子是快速支付系統「轉數快」成功推出。

中國內地與香港資本市場的互聯互通計劃推出優化措施，以及粵港澳大灣區的發展，令香港作為進入中國內地主要門戶的獨特地位進一步加強。香港作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位亦更為穩固，本港人民幣金融活動蓬勃發展。

與此同時，金管局致力開拓新機遇，進一步提升香港金融平台的競爭力，包括基建融資、企業財資中心及綠色債券市場。金管局亦加強向海外及內地持份者宣傳香港優勢的市場推廣計劃。在國際層面，金管局於多個區內及國際委員會扮演領導角色，明確體現了香港在相關國際工作的專業知識及承擔。

# 概覽

為加強香港作為亞洲金融科技樞紐的地位，金管局致力落實於2017年9月公布、旨在促進銀行及支付行業開發與應用金融科技的7項措施。該7項推動智慧銀行的措施於年內取得的主要進展包括：

- 成功推出快速支付系統「轉數快」，全面接通不同銀行及儲值支付工具（統稱「電子錢包」）
- 發布銀行業開放應用程式介面（開放API）框架及促進業界落實開放API；
- 提升金融科技研究及人才培訓；
- 加強跨境金融科技合作；
- 修訂《虛擬銀行的認可》指引，並處理虛擬銀行牌照申請；
- 「金融科技監管沙盒」升級版（FSS 2.0）運作順暢；及
- 擴展「銀行易」以促進銀行採用金融合規科技。

金管局轄下金融科技促進辦公室(FFO)，聯同金管局各銀行部門在推動落實上述措施方面擔當重要角色。

隨着中國內地與香港資本市場的互聯互通計劃優化措施的落實，香港作為進入中國內地主要門戶的獨特地位進一步加強。「債券通」全面實施即時貨銀兩訖(DvP)結算模式及國務院宣布境外投資者投資中國境內債券市場的稅務寛免安排，進一步提升計劃的效率及吸引力。金管局亦與內地當局緊密合作，探討及實施多項金融配套措施，便利在粵港澳大灣區（大灣區）生活、工作及營商的個人和企業。香港離岸人民幣業務繼續蓬勃發展，人民幣存款資金池全年上升6%至6,577億元人民幣；人民幣即時支付結算(RTGS)系統平均每日交易額達到10,101億元人民幣的高水平。

金管局積極開拓進一步提升香港金融平台競爭力的新機會。為促進香港債券市場的發展，金管局落實《財政預算案》所提出的「債券資助先導計劃」，為首次在香港發行債券的機構提供資助，並與政府緊密合作修訂法例，擴大「合資格債務票據計劃」下可獲稅務豁免的債券投資收入範圍。金管局亦加強市場推廣活動，向海外及內地持份者宣傳香港的優勢，包括舉辦多項大型及專題外展活動推廣香港為綠色金融、基建融資及企業財資中心樞紐。

在國際層面，金管局領導多個區內及國際委員會。金管局現正擔任金融穩定理事會轄下監管合作常設委員會主席、巴塞爾銀行監管委員會（巴塞爾委員會）轄下監管及實施準則小組，以及東亞及太平洋地區中央銀行會議(EMEAP) 轄下金融市場工作小組主席。

香港金融基建的安全及有效運作，為香港作為國際金融中心的地位奠定穩固基礎。處理銀行同業交易的4個RTGS系統、債務工具中央結算系統（CMU系統）及香港交易資料儲存庫（香港儲存庫）在2018年達到100%的系統可供使用率，高於99.95%的目標水平。透過於內地兩個中央證券託管機構的帳戶，CMU系統繼續協助結算「債券通」北向通交易，以及替相關CMU系統成員持有內地債務證券。

為促進零售支付業的整體安全及效率，金管局於8月根據《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》（《支付條例》）指定多兩個零售支付系統，使其運作受到金管局監察。迄今受金管局監察的指定零售支付系統增至6個。金管局亦對16個儲值支付工具持牌人進行監管。有關持牌人積極推出新產品及服務，致力為客戶提供更多選擇及更佳的用戶體驗。與此同時，電子支票與電子帳單及繳費服務涵蓋範圍，進一步擴展至包括香港與整個廣東省的跨境支付交易。

# 2018年回顧

# 香港作為亞洲的金融科技樞紐

# 推動智慧銀行的措施

金管局於2017年9月公布7項推動智慧銀行的措施，旨在協助銀行業提升至更高層次，並把握銀行與科技結合帶來的龐大機遇。金管局於年內在落實這些措施及為香港金融生態轉型方面，進展良好。

# 「轉數快」

「轉數快」於9月成功啟動，方便銀行及儲值支付工具用戶隨時隨地進行港元及人民幣的跨行即時資金轉帳，用戶只需輸入收款人的手機號碼或電郵地址。共有21間銀行（包括大部分零售銀行）及10間儲值支付工具營運商已加入該系統，為客戶提供即時支付服務及╱或帳戶綁定服務。

「轉數快」在3.5個月內已接獲超過200萬個登記，相對香港人口比例27%。該系統自推出以來處理超過480萬宗交易，涉及總額逾1,049億港元及27.5億元人民幣。

金管局於同月推出香港零售支付共用二維碼標準及相關流動應用程式「香港共用二維碼」(HKQR)，是全球首創將多個二維碼整合成為個綜合二維碼的流動應用程式，方便商戶尤其中小企以同一個二維碼接受不同支付服務營運商的支付方案，無需向客戶展示多個二維碼。

# 開放應用程式介面

開放API是指透過向第三方服務供應商開放銀行的相關數據，更好更方便地融合銀行與其他行業的服務。用家單用一個系統就能在安全環境下享受綜合服務。為促進銀行界研發及提供開放API，金管局於7月發布開放API框架。該框架採用風險為本原則，並分4個階段落實各項開放API功能。截至2019年1月底，20間銀行已開放第一階段約500個開放API接口，涵蓋逾1,000項產品及服務的資料。

# 科研及人才培訓

建基於金管局主導的貿易融資概念驗證成果由香港多間銀行組成的聯盟於10月啟動以分布式分類帳技術(DLT)為基礎的貿易融資平台「貿易聯動」。該平台旨在透過數碼化貿易文件及自動化貿易融資流程，減低失誤及詐騙風險。截至2018年底，已有12間銀行加入成為該聯盟成員。「貿易聯動」與歐洲貿易融資平台「we.trade」於10月簽署《諒解備忘錄》，進行對接雙方平台的概念驗證。金管局亦同步探討「貿易聯動」與其他地區對接的機會，包括與新加坡金融管理局合作推出「全球貿易連接網絡」。

金管局總裁陳德霖先生（左）於「貿易聯動」啟動儀式上。

為培育更多金融科技專才，金管局於1月與香港應用科技研究院（應科院）合作推出「金融科技人才培育計劃」升級版(FCAS 2.0)。FCAS 2.0設有4個項目，適合處於不同職涯發展階段的年輕人才。計劃下有200多名學生受惠。

金管局總裁陳德霖先生（左二）與數碼港主席林家禮博士（左一）、香港應科院主席王明鑫先生（右二）及香港科技園公司行政總裁黃克強先生（右一）出席FCAS 2.0啟動儀式。

# 跨境合作

繼於2017年與深圳市人民政府金融發展服務辦公室（深圳金融辦）簽署《諒解備忘錄》後，金管局繼續加強與深圳的金融科技合作。當中包括金管局贊助「深圳金融科技暑期實習計劃」，讓50名學生到深圳多間著名公司進行為期6星期的實習，體驗當地的金融科技生態；另與深圳金融辦第二次合辦「深港金融科技創新獎」。

金管局副總裁李達志先生（右二）與首批深圳金融科技暑期實習生交談。

金管局亦於2018年與瑞士金融市場監督管理局、波蘭金融監管局、阿布扎比國際金融中心金融服務監管局及巴西中央銀行簽署金融科技合作協議，促進金融科技合作。

在8月，金管局與11間金融監管當局和相關機構公布「全球金融創新網絡」計劃。該網絡旨在為創新型公司提供更有效方式與監管機構進行互動，並促進監管機構之間就創新相關議題的合作。

# 虛擬銀行

引入虛擬銀行將會為香港金融科技應用增添新動力，並為數碼銀行客戶帶來嶄新體驗。虛擬銀行以個人或中小企等零售客戶為對象，因此亦有助促進普及金融。經公眾諮詢，金管局於5月發出《虛擬銀行的認可》指引修訂本，並於8月底接獲約30宗申請。

# 金融科技監管沙盒

年內沙盒的使用穩步上升。為協助建立金融合規科技的生態系統，沙盒於9月起開放予金融合規科技的項目。

截至2018年底，共有42項金融科技或科技產品獲准使用沙盒進行測試，其中28項已完成試行，有關產品亦已於其後推出市場。金管局另接獲220項使用「金融科技監管聊天室」的個案，希望在金融科技項目構思初期取得監管反饋意見。其中有約70%的個案來自科技公司。

# Hong Kong's Status as an International Financial Center

Strengthening Hong Kong's position as an international financial center is one of the Monetary Authority's main responsibilities. Seven measures aimed at promoting the development and application of fintech in the banking and payment industries have made good progress this year, with the successful launch of the fast payment system "FPS" (Quick Pay) serving as the best example.

The optimization measures introduced for the Stock Connect program between mainland China and Hong Kong, along with the development of the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macau Greater Bay Area, have further strengthened Hong Kong's unique position as a primary gateway to mainland China. Hong Kong's status as an offshore RMB business hub has also become more solidified, with robust RMB financial activities in the territory.

Meanwhile, the HKMA is committed to pursuing new opportunities to further enhance the competitiveness of Hong Kong's financial platform, including infrastructure financing, corporate treasury centers, and the green bond market. The HKMA has also intensified its market promotion campaigns highlighting Hong Kong's advantages to overseas and mainland stakeholders. On the international stage, the HKMA plays leadership roles in numerous regional and international committees, clearly demonstrating Hong Kong's expertise and commitment in related international endeavors.

# Overview

To strengthen Hong Kong's position as a financial technology hub in Asia, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has been committed to implementing the seven measures announced in September 2017, aimed at promoting the development and application of financial technology in the banking and payment industries. The main progress achieved during the year in implementing the seven measures to promote smart banking includes:

Successfully launched the fast payment system "Zhuanshu Kuai", comprehensively connecting different banks and stored value payment tools (collectively referred to as "electronic wallets");  
Released the framework for the banking industry's open application programming interface (open API) and promoted the industry to implement open APIs;  
Enhanced financial technology research and talent training;  
Strengthened cross-border financial technology cooperation;  
Revised the "Approval of Virtual Banks" guidelines and processed virtual bank license applications;  
The upgraded version of the "Financial Technology Regulatory Sandbox" (FSS 2.0) operates smoothly; and  
Expanded "Banking Easy" to promote banks' adoption of financial compliance technology.

The Office for Fintech Promotion under the HKMA (FFO) plays an important role in promoting and implementing the aforementioned measures in collaboration with the HKMA's various banking departments.

As the optimization measures of the linkage plan between China's mainland and Hong Kong's capital markets are implemented, Hong Kong's unique position as a key gateway to the mainland further strengthens. The full implementation of the real-time gross settlement (DvP) settlement mechanism under the "Bond Connect" program, along with the State Council's announcement of tax exemption arrangements for overseas investors investing in China's domestic bond market, further enhances the program's efficiency and appeal. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has also closely collaborated with mainland authorities to explore and implement various financial supporting measures, facilitating individuals and enterprises living, working, and conducting business in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macau Greater Bay Area (GBA). Offshore RMB business in Hong Kong continues to thrive, with the deposit funds pool increasing by 6% year-on-year to 657.7 billion yuan; the average daily transaction volume of the RMB real-time gross settlement (RTGS) system reached a high level of 1.0101 trillion yuan.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is actively exploring new opportunities to further enhance the competitiveness of Hong Kong's financial platform. To promote the development of Hong Kong's bond market, the HKMA has implemented the "Bond Grant Pioneer Scheme" proposed in the Budget, providing grants to institutions issuing bonds for the first time in Hong Kong. It has also closely collaborated with the government to revise relevant legislation, expanding the scope of bond investment income eligible for tax exemption under the "Qualifying Debt Instruments Scheme." In addition, the HKMA has intensified market promotion activities, highlighting Hong Kong's advantages to overseas and mainland stakeholders, including organizing various large-scale and specialized outreach events to promote Hong Kong as a hub for green finance, infrastructure financing, and corporate treasury centers.

At the international level, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) leads multiple regional and international committees. The HKMA is currently serving as the Chair of the Regulatory Cooperation Standing Committee under the Financial Stability Board, the Chair of the Regulatory and Implementation Standards Group under the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, and the Chair of the Financial Markets Working Group under the East Asia and Pacific Central Banks Meeting (EMEAP).

The secure and efficient operation of Hong Kong's financial infrastructure lays a solid foundation for Hong Kong's status as an international financial center. In 2018, four RTGS systems, the Debt Securities Central Settlement System (CMU system), and the Hong Kong Trading Data Repository (Hong Kong Storage Repository) achieved 100% system availability, surpassing the target level of 99.95%. The CMU system continued to assist in settling Bond Connect Northbound transactions through accounts with two central securities custody institutions in mainland China, as well as holding mainland debt securities for relevant CMU system members.

To promote the overall safety and efficiency of the retail payment industry, the HKMA designated two more retail payment systems in August under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Payment Tools Ordinance (Payment Ordinance), subjecting their operations to HKMA supervision. As of now, the number of designated retail payment systems under HKMA supervision has increased to six. The HKMA also regulates 16 licensed stored value payment tool operators. These licensees actively launch new products and services, striving to provide customers with more choices and a better user experience. At the same time, the coverage of electronic cheques and electronic bill and payment services has further expanded to include cross-border payment transactions between Hong Kong and the entire Guangdong Province.

# 2018 in Review

# Hong Kong as Asia's Fintech Hub

# Measures to Promote Smart Banking

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority announced seven measures to promote smart banking in September 2017, aiming to help the banking industry reach a higher level and seize the significant opportunities brought by the integration of banking and technology. The HKMA has made good progress in implementing these measures and transforming Hong Kong's financial ecosystem during the year.

# Fast Turnover

The Fast Transfer Service was successfully launched in September, enabling banks and value-added payment tool users to make instant cross-bank transfers of Hong Kong dollars and Chinese yuan anytime and anywhere. Users only need to input the recipient's mobile phone number or email address. A total of 21 banks (including most retail banks) and 10 value-added payment tool operators have joined the system, providing customers with instant payment services and/or account binding services.

"Fast Transfer" has received over 2 million registrations within 3.5 months, accounting for 27% of Hong Kong's population. Since its launch, the system has processed over 4.8 million transactions, involving a total amount of over 104.9 billion HK dollars and 2.75 billion RMB.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority launched the Hong Kong Retail Payment Shared QR Code Standard and the related mobile application "HKQR" in the same month. It is the world's first mobile application to integrate multiple QR codes into a single comprehensive QR code, making it convenient for merchants, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, to accept payment solutions from different payment service providers using a single QR code, without needing to display multiple QR codes to customers.

# Open Application Interface

Open API refers to the practice of opening up banks' relevant data to third-party service providers, enabling more effective and convenient integration of banking services with those of other industries. Users can enjoy comprehensive services in a secure environment by using a single system. To promote the development and provision of open APIs in the banking sector, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority released an open API framework in July. The framework adopts a risk-based principle and implements various open API functions in four stages. As of the end of January 2019, 20 banks had opened approximately 500 open API interfaces in the first phase, covering data on over 1,000 products and services.

# Scientific Research and Talent Training

Launched in October by a consortium of Hong Kong banks, the trade finance platform "TradeLink" is based on distributed ledger technology (DLT) and builds upon the results of the trade finance concept validation led by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA). The platform aims to reduce errors and fraud risks by digitizing trade documents and automating trade financing processes. By the end of 2018, 12 banks had joined as members of the consortium. In October, "TradeLink" signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the European trade finance platform "we.trade" to conduct a concept validation for connecting both platforms. The HKMA also explored opportunities for "TradeLink" to connect with other regions, including collaborating with the Monetary Authority of Singapore to launch the "Global Trade Connect Network."

Mr. Chan Tak-lun, Governor of the Monetary Authority (left), at the "Trade Linkage" launch ceremony.

To cultivate more fintech specialists, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) launched the upgraded version of the "Financial Technology Talent Cultivation Program" (FCAS 2.0) in collaboration with the Hong Kong Applied Science and Technology Research Institute (ASTRI) in January. FCAS 2.0 features four projects suitable for young talents at different career stages. Over 200 students have benefited from the program.

Mr. Chan Tak-lun, Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (second from the left), Dr. Lam Ka-lik, Chairman of Digital Harbor (first from the left), Mr. Wang Ming-xin, Chairman of the Hong Kong Institute of Applied Sciences (second from the right), and Mr. Huang Ke-qiang, Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Science and Technology Parks Company (first from the right) attended the FCAS 2.0 Launch Ceremony.

# Cross-border Cooperation

Following the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding with the Shenzhen Municipal People's Government Financial Development Service Office (Shenzhen Financial Office) in 2017, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has continued to strengthen its fintech cooperation with Shenzhen. This includes the HKMA's sponsorship of the "Shenzhen Fintech Summer Internship Program," which allows 50 students to intern at several renowned companies in Shenzhen for six weeks, experiencing the local fintech ecosystem; and the second joint organization of the "Shenzhen-Hong Kong Fintech Innovation Award" with the Shenzhen Financial Office.

Mr. Li Dazhi, Deputy Chairman of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (second from the right), is talking to the first batch of Shenzhen financial technology summer interns.

The HKMA also signed fintech cooperation agreements with the Swiss Financial Market Supervisory Authority, the Polish Financial Supervision Authority, the Financial Services Regulatory Authority of the Abu Dhabi Global Market, and the Central Bank of Brazil in 2018 to promote fintech cooperation.

In August, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) and 11 financial regulatory authorities and related institutions announced the "Global Financial Innovation Network" plan. The network aims to provide innovative companies with more effective ways to interact with regulatory authorities and promote cooperation among regulatory authorities on innovation-related issues.

# Virtual Bank

Introducing virtual banks will provide new momentum to Hong Kong's fintech applications and bring new experiences to digital banking customers. Virtual banks target retail customers such as individuals and SMEs, thereby also helping to promote financial inclusion. Following public consultation, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority issued a revised version of the guidelines on "Recognition of Virtual Banks" in May and received approximately 30 applications by the end of August.

# FinTech Regulatory Sandbox

The usage of the sandbox has been steadily increasing throughout the year. To help establish the financial compliance technology ecosystem, the sandbox was made available to financial compliance technology projects beginning in September.

As of the end of 2018, a total of 42 financial technology or technology products had been approved to use the sandbox for testing, of which 28 had completed trials and the related products were subsequently launched into the market. The HKMA also received an additional 220 cases using the "Financial Technology Regulatory Chatroom," seeking regulatory feedback at the early stage of fintech project development. Of these cases, approximately 70% came from technology companies.

# 儲備管理

2018年對投資者而言是困難的一年，投資環境備受多項風險因素困擾，包括美國利率持續正常化引發金融狀況收緊、主要經濟體之間的貿易摩擦升級，以及全球多處民粹主義抬頭及地緣政治風險加劇。環球股市普遍向下，美國國庫券收益率亦隨着美國聯邦儲備局4次加息而上升。在美息趨升下，美元轉強。部分新興市場面對國內嚴峻的政治及經濟壓力，其貨幣顯著下挫。儘管投資環境充滿挑戰，外匯基金在2018年仍錄得109億港元投資收入。

# 外匯基金

根據《外匯基金條例》，外匯基金的首要目的是直接或間接影響港元匯價，亦可運用於保持香港貨幣及金融體系穩定健全，藉此保持香港作為國際金融中心的地位。金管局根據財政司司長轉授的權力及轉授權力的條款，就外匯基金的運用及投資管理向財政司司長負責。

# 外匯基金的管理

# 投資目標及組合架構

外匯基金諮詢委員會為外匯基金制定下列投資目標：

(a) 保障資本；
(b) 確保整體貨幣基礎在任何時候都由流通性極高的美元資產提供十足支持；
(c) 確保流動資金足以維持貨幣及金融穩定；以及
(d) 在符合上述(a)至(c)項的前提下盡量爭取投資回報，以保障基金的長期購買力。

以上目標全面顧及外匯基金的法定目的，並已於外匯基金的組合結構及目標資產配置中反映。

外匯基金大致上分成兩個主要組合：支持組合及投資組合。支持組合持有流通性極高的美元資產，按照貨幣發行局制度的規定為貨幣基礎提供十足支持。投資組合主要投資於經濟合作與發展組織成員國的債市及股市，以保障資產的價值及長期購買力。

為能更妥善管理風險及提高中長期回報，金管局以審慎及循序漸進方式將外匯基金的部分資產分散投資至較多元化的資產類別，包括新興巿場及內地債券與股票、私募股權（包括基建）及房地產。新興巿場及內地債券與股票由投資組合持有，私募股權及房地產投資則由長期增長組合持有。長期增長組合的市值上限為外匯基金累計盈餘的三分之一及未來基金與外匯基金附屬公司存款中與長期增長組合掛鈎部分的總和。

策略性資產組合於2007年設立，以持有政府基於策略性目的而為外匯基金帳目購入的香港交易及結算所有限公司股份。由於這個組合性質獨特，因此外匯基金的投資表現評估並無將其包括在內。

# 於外匯基金的存款

外匯基金不時接受財政儲備、政府基金及法定組織的存款，利率一般與投資組合的表現掛鈎，但主要以未來基金除外。未來基金存款的利率與投資組合及長期增長組合的表現掛鈎，實際利率視乎組合比重而定。於2018年底，未來基金在投資組合與長期增長組合的比重約為50:50。

# 投資程序

外匯基金的投資程序分別以策略性資產配置及戰略性資產配置作基礎。策略性資產配置，即投資基準反映的配置情況，顯示外匯基金為達到投資目標而可作出的長線資產配置。外匯基金以策略性配置作為指引，對資產進行戰略性配置，以爭取超越基準的回報。因此，實際配置往往會與基準配置（亦即策略性配置）有所偏離，而實際與基準配置之間的差距稱為「戰略性偏離」。財政司司長經諮詢外匯基金諮詢委員會後制定投資基準及循跡誤差限額，金管局獲授權決定戰略性資產配置及定出戰略性偏離的容許範圍。投資組合經理可在戰略性偏離的容許範圍內選持倉盤，從短期市場變化中獲利。

# 投資管理

# 直接投資

金管局於8月成立外匯基金投資辦公室，專責投資及相關風險管理職能。該辦公室職員負責直接管理外匯基金約72%的投資，包括整個支持組合及部分投資組合。該部分的投資組合投資於環球定息市場，並透過衍生工具執行外匯基金的宏觀風險管理策略。

# 外聘投資經理

除透過內部職員管理資產外，金管局亦僱用外聘投資經理負責管理外匯基金約28%的資產，包括所有上市股票組合及其他特別資產。僱用外聘投資經理的目的是要運用市場上最佳的專業投資技術為外匯基金投資，以取得可持續回報，並讓外匯基金受惠於多元化及互補的投資方式，以及汲取市場心得與專業投資技術知識。

僱用外聘投資經理的相關支出包括基金管理與託管費、交易費、預扣稅及其他稅項。這些支出主要受市場因素影響而每年不同。

# 風險管理及監察

投資環境越趨複雜，突顯風險管理的重要。金管局為內部及外聘投資經理所管理的投資組合均訂立嚴格管控措施及投資指引，並密切監察對指引及法規的遵守情況。金管局已加強風險評估，以配合外匯基金越趨多元化的投資；另採用風險管控工具來評估在正常及極度不利市況下的市場風險。金管局亦進行詳細的投資表現因素分析，以識別促成不同表現的成因，藉此評估如何充分利用內部及外聘投資經理的投資管理技術。

# 負責任投資

金管局支持負責任投資。例如，金管局已採納證券及期貨事務監察委員會公布的《負責任的擁有權原則》。該套原則旨在協助投資者釐定如何以最佳方法履行其於香港上市公司投資的擁有權責任。就外匯基金的管理而言，金管局已就環境、社會及管治因素制定內部指引，適用於外聘基金經理的甄選、委任及監察程序。獲委任負責主動式管理香港股票組合的外聘基金經理，須在管理有關投資時遵守《負責任的擁有權原則》。整體而言，金管局已將環境、社會及管治因素納入投資及相關監察活動的內部程序。金管局會密切注視環境、社會及管治因素的相關標準的發展，並評估如何能夠將這些標準進一步融入投資程序。此外，為促進負責任投資的國際合作，金管局已成為非牟利組織FCLTGlobal的成員，該組織旨在推動長遠目標為本的業務及投資決定。

# Reserve Management

2018 was a challenging year for investors, as the investment environment was plagued by multiple risk factors, including the tightening of financial conditions caused by the continued normalization of US interest rates, escalating trade tensions between major economies, and rising populism and escalating geopolitical risks in various parts of the world. Global stock markets generally declined, and US Treasury yields also rose following the Federal Reserve's four interest rate hikes. With rising US interest rates, the dollar strengthened. Some emerging markets faced severe domestic political and economic pressures, leading to significant currency depreciation. Despite the challenging investment environment, the Exchange Fund recorded HK$10.9 billion in investment income in 2018.

# Foreign Exchange Fund

According to the Exchange Fund Ordinance, the primary purpose of the Exchange Fund is to directly or indirectly influence the exchange rate of the Hong Kong dollar, and it may also be used to maintain the stability and soundness of Hong Kong's monetary and financial systems, thereby preserving Hong Kong's status as an international financial center. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is responsible to the Financial Secretary for the use and investment management of the Exchange Fund, based on the powers delegated by the Financial Secretary and the terms of the sub-delegation.

# Management of the Foreign Exchange Fund

# Investment Objectives and Portfolio Structure

The Foreign Exchange Fund Advisory Committee sets the following investment objectives for the Foreign Exchange Fund:

(a) Ensure capital preservation;
(b) Ensure that the overall monetary base is fully supported at all times by highly liquid U.S. assets;
(c) Ensure that adequate liquidity is sufficient to maintain monetary and financial stability; and
(d) Strive to maximize investment returns, subject to the above (a) to (c), in order to safeguard the fund's long-term purchasing power.

The aforementioned objectives fully consider the statutory purposes of the Exchange Fund and have already been reflected in the Exchange Fund's portfolio structure and target asset allocation.

The Exchange Fund is generally divided into two main portfolios: the Support Portfolio and the Investment Portfolio. The Support Portfolio holds highly liquid USD assets, providing full support for the monetary base in accordance with the currency issuance system. The Investment Portfolio primarily invests in debt and equity markets of OECD member countries to preserve asset value and long-term purchasing power.

To more effectively manage risks and enhance long-term returns, the HKMA is dispersing part of the Reserve Fund's assets into more diversified asset classes in a prudent and gradual manner, including emerging market and mainland China bonds and stocks, private equity (including infrastructure), and real estate. Emerging market and mainland China bonds and stocks are held by the investment portfolio, while private equity and real estate investments are held by the long-term growth portfolio. The market value cap of the long-term growth portfolio is set at one-third of the Reserve Fund's accumulated surplus, plus the total amount of deposits from the Future Fund and the Reserve Fund's affiliated companies that are linked to the long-term growth portfolio.

The strategic asset portfolio was established in 2007 to hold shares in Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited purchased by the government for strategic purposes under the Exchange Fund account. Due to the unique nature of this portfolio, the Exchange Fund's investment performance assessment does not include it.

# Deposits in the Foreign Exchange Fund

The Exchange Fund occasionally accepts deposits from fiscal reserves, government funds, and statutory organizations, with interest rates generally linked to the performance of the investment portfolio, except for the Future Fund. The interest rate on Future Fund deposits is linked to the performance of the investment portfolio and the long-term growth portfolio, with the actual interest rate depending on the allocation weights of the portfolios. By the end of 2018, the allocation of the Future Fund to the investment portfolio and the long-term growth portfolio was approximately 50:50.

# Investment Procedure

The investment process of the Exchange Fund is based on strategic asset allocation and tactical asset allocation. Strategic asset allocation, which reflects the investment benchmark, shows the long-term asset allocation the Exchange Fund can make to achieve its investment objectives. The Exchange Fund uses strategic allocation as a guide to perform tactical allocation in pursuit of returns exceeding the benchmark. Therefore, actual allocation often deviates from the benchmark (i.e., strategic allocation), and the gap between actual and benchmark allocation is referred to as "strategic deviation." The Financial Secretary, after consulting the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, sets the investment benchmark and tracking error limit. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is authorized to determine the strategic asset allocation and set the allowable range for strategic deviation. Portfolio managers can select holdings within the allowable strategic deviation range to profit from short-term market fluctuations.

# Investment Management

# Direct Investment

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority established the Foreign Exchange Fund Investment Office in August to specialize in investment and related risk management functions. Staff of the office are responsible for directly managing approximately 72% of the Foreign Exchange Fund's investments, including the entire supporting portfolio and part of the investment portfolio. These investment portfolios are invested in global fixed-income markets and implement the Foreign Exchange Fund's macro risk management strategies through derivative instruments.

# External Investment Manager

In addition to managing assets through internal staff, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority also employs external investment managers to oversee approximately 28% of the Foreign Exchange Fund's assets, including all listed stock portfolios and other special assets. The purpose of employing external investment managers is to utilize the best professional investment techniques available in the market to achieve sustainable returns, allowing the Foreign Exchange Fund to benefit from diversified and complementary investment approaches, as well as to gain insights from market expertise and professional investment techniques.

Expenses related to hiring external investment managers include fund management and custody fees, transaction fees, withholding taxes, and other taxes. These expenses primarily vary each year due to market factors.

# Risk Management and Supervision

As the investment environment becomes increasingly complex, the importance of risk management is highlighted. The HKMA has established strict control measures and investment guidelines for investment portfolios managed by both internal and external investment managers, and closely monitors compliance with these guidelines and regulations. The HKMA has strengthened risk assessment to align with the increasingly diversified investments of the Exchange Fund; it also employs risk control tools to evaluate market risks under normal and extremely adverse market conditions. The HKMA also conducts detailed factor analysis of investment performance to identify the causes behind different performance outcomes, thereby assessing how to fully leverage the investment management techniques of both internal and external investment managers.

# Responsible Investment

The HKMA supports responsible investment. For example, the HKMA has adopted the "Principles of Responsible Ownership" published by the Securities and Futures Ordinance. These principles aim to assist investors in determining the best ways to fulfill their ownership responsibilities when investing in Hong Kong-listed companies. In terms of the management of the Exchange Fund, the HKMA has established internal guidelines on environmental, social, and governance factors applicable to the selection, appointment, and supervision of external fund managers. External fund managers appointed to actively manage Hong Kong equity portfolios must adhere to the Principles of Responsible Ownership when managing such investments. Overall, the HKMA has incorporated environmental, social, and governance factors into its internal procedures for investment and related monitoring activities. The HKMA closely monitors the development of relevant standards on environmental, social, and governance factors and evaluates how these standards can be further integrated into investment processes. In addition, to promote international cooperation on responsible investment, the HKMA has become a member of the non-profit organization FCLTGlobal, which aims to promote business and investment decisions based on long-term objectives.

# Performance of the Foreign Exchange Fund

# The Financial Markets of 2018

In 2018, multiple risk factors that had been underestimated by the market began to emerge one by one, including the pace of U.S. interest rate normalization, the impact of U.S. government trade policies and protectionism on global trade, and geopolitical risks. Global financial markets thus experienced significant fluctuations and adjustments.

The escalation of the US-China trade dispute has caused investors great concern, with emerging markets and Hong Kong stocks experiencing repeated declines since the end of January, and the Hang Seng Index falling as much as 27% from its peak in that month. Starting from the fourth quarter, major European and American stock markets also declined significantly, recording two-digit percentage drops. Overall for 2018, global stock markets generally declined, with the MSCI Global Index, which covers developed market stocks, falling by 10.4%, and the MSCI Emerging Markets Index also falling by 16.6%.

In the bond market, U.S. Treasury yields rose broadly in 2018 due to the normalization of U.S. monetary policy. However, the bond market still experienced fluctuations during the year. For example, the 10-year U.S. Treasury yield rose from approximately 2.5% at the beginning of the year to a 7-year high of 3.2% in November, but by the end of the year, it declined to 2.7% due to investors' concerns over the U.S.-China trade dispute and a shift towards more conservative investments.

In the foreign exchange market, the US dollar strengthened throughout the year in line with US interest rate hikes. The US Dollar Index rose by 4.4%, while major currencies such as the euro and the yuan depreciated against the dollar by about 5%. Additionally, some emerging markets were affected by domestic political instability and economic instability, leading to further declines in their currencies. For example, the Argentine peso and the Turkish lira depreciated against the dollar by about 50% and 30% respectively. In contrast, the yen appreciated against the dollar by 2.7% driven by safe-haven investment demand.

# Media Relations and Social Media

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority maintains close contact with the media to enhance its transparency and promote public understanding of its policies and work. In 2018, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority held 96 public media events, including 21 press conferences, 11 on-site interviews, and 64 other public events. In addition, 39 media interviews were arranged, and 462 bilingual press releases were issued throughout the year. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority also handles a large number of media inquiries daily.

# Public Inquiry

The Public Inquiry Service serves as an effective channel for citizens to understand the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's main functions and operations. In 2018, it handled 9,950 inquiries, with approximately half relating to banking policies and regulations, banking consumer matters, and banknotes and coins, particularly the coin collection program, banking products and services, guidelines and announcements related to the banking sector, the Fast Payment System "FPS", virtual banks, and the 2018 Hong Kong new banknote series.

# Publications

In addition to the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's Annual Report, the Authority published two Semi-Annual Reports on the Monetary and Financial Situation and four Quarterly Reports in 2018. It also regularly updated the Financial Data Monthly Bulletin, providing the latest and specialized data and analysis on Hong Kong's monetary, banking, and economic affairs. Furthermore, the Authority published a total of 13 "Hui Si" articles, elaborating on various specialized topics related to its work.

# Financial Authority Website

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority's official website (www.hkma.gov.hk) provides over 60,000 pages of information in English and Chinese (both simplified and traditional characters), facilitating the public's access to the Authority's latest information. The website also maintains the "Authorized Institutions and Local Representatives Register" and "Authorized Institutions Securities Business Staff Register" under Article 20 of the Banking Ordinance, as well as the "Stored Value Payment Tool Licensees Register" under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Payment Instruments Ordinance. The website features special topic pages and prominent quick links to alert the public about the Authority's new measures, such as the Fast Payment System, as well as important and timely matters, such as being vigilant against phone scams and the locations where cash-in-vehicles are parked under the coin collection program.

To promote the implementation of open application programming interfaces (APIs) in the banking sector, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has taken the initiative, starting in July to provide open APIs on its website, facilitating public access to the HKMA's key information. The first batch of 50 open API data sets was successfully launched in July, covering areas most frequently accessed by the public, such as statistical data on the banking system and the Exchange Fund, as well as press releases and cash-in-transit vehicle schedules. The remaining 80 data sets will be rolled out in phases before mid-2019. To further facilitate public access to the HKMA's latest news and information on its website, the HKMA is comprehensively revising the website's design and content to make it more user-friendly. The newly redesigned website is expected to be launched within 2019.

The Financial Authority leads by example in promoting the development and application of open APIs.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority Information Centre is located on the 55th floor of Phase 2, International Finance Centre, and aims to introduce the work of the Monetary Authority and enhance public understanding of monetary and banking matters. The Information Centre is divided into two parts: the Exhibition Hall and the Library, and is open to the public for visits six days a week. The Exhibition Hall introduces the work of the Monetary Authority and the development of Hong Kong's currency and banking sector, and also provides reading materials and exhibits for studying Hong Kong's currency, banking sector, and financial affairs.

The Currency Exhibition Area at the Information Center introduces the design, anti-counterfeiting features, manufacturing process, and other interesting facts about Hong Kong banknotes and coins. The exhibition area underwent a renovation in the first quarter of 2018, incorporating various interactive elements, such as games that combine learning with fun, allowing visitors to gain knowledge about Hong Kong currency while enjoying the experience. Additionally, the Currency Exhibition Area features a new artistic Bauhinia tree, crafted from 2,018 transparent cubic blocks made from shredded banknotes no longer suitable for circulation, complementing another mosaic artwork in the exhibition area constructed from Hong Kong coins. The newly renovated Currency Exhibition Area reopened on August 16.

The information center provides guided tours for visitors. During the year, the information center welcomed over 59,000 visitors and provided more than 580 guided tours for schools and other groups (Figure 3). Since its opening in December 2003, the information center has welcomed over 705,000 visitors in total. The library adjacent to the exhibition hall houses over 26,000 books, journals, and other publications for research on topics such as Hong Kong currency, banking, finance, and central banking matters. # Hong Kong Monetary Authority Employees

The HKMA is part of the government structure but hires staff under non-civil service terms to attract individuals with appropriate experience and specialized knowledge. As a public institution, the HKMA continuously streamlines work processes to enhance efficiency and cost-effectiveness. The HKMA strives to maintain a streamlined and flexible organizational structure and, as much as possible, implements new measures and copes with the increasing workload through the reallocation of existing staff.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is an employer that provides equal employment opportunities and ensures that employees can work in a discrimination-free environment. The Authority's equal opportunity policy applies to recruitment, compensation and benefits, performance appraisal, promotion, transfer/training opportunities, and general conduct standards.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority hires, trains, and maintains a professional and excellent work team to fulfill policy objectives and flexibly adapt to changes in work requirements. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority requires its employees to maintain high standards of integrity and ethics, always adhering to strict personal conduct and integrity norms, and prioritizing the best interests of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority.

# 2018 Organizational Structure Changes

The Office of the Fund Investment was established on August 1st, replacing the previous investment and related risk management functions that were managed by the Reserve Management Department and the Risk Management and Supervision Department. The establishment of the Office of the Fund Investment highlights the Authority's investment functions, enhances its institutional image, and enables more flexible responses to market changes, thereby supporting the ongoing expansion and diversification of the Fund's investment activities.

# Compensation and Benefits Policy and Compensation Review Mechanism

The Financial Secretary consults the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee on the views of the Governance Committee under his jurisdiction, and references market salary levels and practices to determine the compensation and employment terms for HKMA staff. The compensation package includes cash compensation and a provident fund, along with some basic benefits. Cash compensation comprises a fixed monthly salary (i.e., basic salary) and a performance-based annual bonus paid once a year.

When the Financial Secretary reviews the salaries of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's employees annually, they seek advice from its governing committee through the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, taking into account the governing committee's assessment of the HKMA's performance over the past year, the results of a financial sector salary survey conducted by an independent human resources consulting firm, and other relevant factors. Individual employees with outstanding work performance may also receive special adjustments to maintain their competitive compensation.

The HKMA allocates approved funds for adjusting annual fixed and variable salaries based on individual employees' work performance; the variable salary system for employees responsible for investments aims to strengthen the link between their investment performance and compensation. The adjustment of fixed salaries and the payment of variable salaries for employees at the level of Assistant Deputy Governor and above are approved by the Financial Secretary after consulting the Governance Committee, and these employees will abstain from meetings discussing salary-related proposals. For employees at the level of Manager and below, the adjustment of fixed salaries and the payment of variable salaries are decided by the HKMA Governor based on the Financial Secretary's authorization and in accordance with the entire approved amount allocated for salary payments.

# 按公平值列帳的金融資產及金融負債的估值

我的目標是就整體財務報表是否不存有任何因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述取得合理保證，並發出包括我意見的審計師報告。合理保證是高水平的保證，但不能確保按審計署審計準則進行的審計定能發現所存有的任何重大錯誤陳述。錯誤陳述可以由欺詐或錯誤引起，如果合理預期它們個別或滙總起來可能影響財務報表使用者所作出的經濟決定，則會被視作重大錯誤陳述。

在根據審計署審計準則進行審計的過程中，我會運用專業判斷並秉持專業懷疑態度。我亦會：

- 識別和評估因欺詐或錯誤而導致財務報表存有重大錯誤陳述的風險；設計及執行審計程序以應對這些風險；以及取得充足和適當的審計憑證，作為我意見的基礎。由於欺詐可能涉及串謀、偽造、蓄意遺漏、虛假陳述，或凌駕內部控制的情況，因此未能發現因欺詐而導致重大錯誤陳述的風險，較未能發現因錯誤而導致者為高；
- 了解與審計相關的內部控制，以設計適當的審計程序。然而，此舉並非旨在對集團內部控制的有效性發表意見；
- 評價金融管理專員所採用的會計政策是否恰當，以及其作出的會計估計和相關資料披露是否合理；
- 判定金融管理專員以持續經營作為會計基礎的做法是否恰當，並根據所得的審計憑證，判定是否存在與事件或情況有關，而且可能對集團持續經營的能力構成重大疑慮的重大不確定性。如果我認為存在重大不確定性，則有必要在審計師報告中請使用者留意財務報表中的相關資料披露。假若所披露的相關資料不足，我便須發出非無保留意見的審計師報告。我的結論是基於截至審計師報告日止所取得的審計憑證。然而，未來事件或情況可能導致集團不能繼續持續經營；
- 評價財務報表的整體列報方式、結構和內容，包括披露資料，以及財務報表是否中肯反映交易和事項；及
- 就集團中實體或業務活動的財務資料獲取充足和適當的審計憑證，以對財務報表發表意見。我負責指導、監督和執行集團審計。我對我的審計意見承擔全部責任。

我會與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通計劃的審計範圍和時間以及重大審計發現等事項，包括我在審計期間識別出內部控制的任何重大缺陷。

我亦會向外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會提交聲明，說明我已符合有關獨立性的相關道德要求，並與他們溝通所有被合理認為可能會影響我獨立性的關係和其他事項，以及在適用的情況下，相關的防範措施。

從與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通的事項中，我會決定哪些事項對本期財務報表的審計最為重要，因而構成關鍵審計事項。我會在審計師報告中描述這些事項，除非法律法規不允許對某件事項作出公開披露，或在極端罕見的情況下，因為有合理預期在我報告中溝通某事項而造成的負面後果將會超過其產生的公眾利益而我決定不應在報告中溝通該事項。

# Independent Auditor's Report to the Financial Secretary

# Opinion

I hereby certify that I have audited the financial statements of the Exchange Fund and its subsidiaries ("the Group"), which include the balance sheets of the Exchange Fund and the Group as at December 31, 2018, the income statements, comprehensive income statements, statements of changes in equity, cash flow statements, and notes to the financial statements, including a summary of significant accounting policies, covering the period ended on that date.

# The Foundation of Opinion

I have conducted the audit in accordance with the instructions issued by the Chief Executive under Section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance and the audit standards of the Audit Office. I believe that the audit evidence I have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for my audit opinion.

# Key Audit Matters

Key audit matters are those that, in my professional judgment, are the most significant for the audit of the financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2018. I addressed these matters during the audit and formation of my opinion on the entire financial statements, and I will not provide separate opinions on these matters.

# Valuation of Financial Assets and Liabilities Measured at Fair Value

Please refer to the footnotes 2.5, 2.6, and 40.1 of the financial statements.

As of December 31, 2018, the Group's financial assets measured at fair value totaled HK$36,935.89 billion, and financial liabilities totaled HK$11,338.29 billion.

The fair value of 93% of such financial assets and all such financial liabilities is based on quoted prices for the same assets or liabilities in active markets (Level 1 inputs), or is estimated using valuation techniques, with the inputs used being based on observable market data (Level 2 inputs).

The fair value of the remaining 7% of the financial assets is estimated using valuation methods, with parameters not based on observable market data (Level 3 parameters). The total related financial assets amount to 27.5631 billion HKD, mainly comprising non-listed investment funds.

Given the substantial amount involved and the estimates, the valuation of financial assets and liabilities accounted for at fair value is a key audit matter.

Regarding the valuation of financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value, audit procedures include:

Understand the valuation procedures for different categories of financial assets and liabilities, including relevant monitoring measures;
Evaluate and test monitoring measures, including related application control measures in computer systems;
Obtain confirmations regarding the valuation, existence, rights and obligations, and completeness of financial assets and liabilities;
If market quotations are used, verify the prices based on independent sources;
If the parameters used in the valuation method are based on observable market data, evaluate whether the valuation method is appropriate and whether the related assumptions are reasonable, as well as verify the parameters based on independent sources; and
If the parameters used in the valuation method are not based on observable market data, evaluate whether the valuation method is appropriate, as well as the reasonableness of the related assumptions and parameters.

# Valuation of Investment Property Carried at Fair Value

Please refer to the footnotes to the financial statements 2.12, 20, and 21.

The Group's investment properties are accounted for at fair value, totaling HKD 25.321 billion as of December 31, 2018. The Group also holds interests in 3 joint ventures and 20 associate companies, which primarily engage in holding overseas investment properties, with the total value of these interests amounting to HKD 44.336 billion. The fair value of these investment properties, regardless of whether held directly by the Group or through joint ventures or associate companies, is primarily determined based on valuations by independent professional valuers. These valuations involve significant judgments and estimates, including the valuation methods and assumptions used.

Regarding the valuation of investment properties accounted for at fair value, audit procedures include:

Obtain and review valuation reports for investment properties held directly by the Group or through joint ventures and joint companies, and verify that the fair value is determined based on the valuations listed in the relevant valuation reports;  
Assess the independence and qualifications of the valuers; and  
Evaluate whether the valuation methods are appropriate, and whether the relevant assumptions and parameters are reasonable.

# Responsibilities of the Financial Management Officer and the Review Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee regarding financial statements

The Financial Management Officer must be responsible for preparing true and fair financial statements in accordance with the Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards issued by the Hong Kong Institute of Accountants and the instructions given by the Chief Executive under Section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance, and implementing the internal controls it deems necessary to ensure that the financial statements do not contain material misstatements due to fraud or error.

When preparing financial statements, the Financial Commissioner must be responsible for assessing the group's ability to continue as a going concern, as well as disclosing matters related to the going concern when applicable, and using the going concern as the basis of accounting.

The Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee is responsible for supervising the group's financial reporting process.

# Responsibility of Auditors for the Audit of Financial Statements

My objective is to obtain reasonable assurance regarding whether the financial statements as a whole do not contain material misstatements resulting from fraud or error, and to issue an auditor's report that includes my opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but it cannot guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with auditing standards will necessarily detect any existing material misstatements. Material misstatements may arise from fraud or error, and they are considered material misstatements if it is reasonably expected that they, individually or in aggregate, may influence the economic decisions made by users of the financial statements.

During the process of conducting audits in accordance with the Audit Office's audit standards, I will apply professional judgment and maintain a professional skeptical attitude. I will also:

Identify and assess the risk of material misstatements in the financial statements due to fraud or error; design and perform audit procedures to address these risks; and obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence as the basis for my opinion. Since fraud may involve collusion, fabrication, intentional omission, false statements, or overriding of internal controls, the risk of not detecting material misstatements due to fraud is higher than the risk of not detecting those due to errors;  
Understand the internal controls relevant to the audit in order to design appropriate audit procedures. However, this is not intended to express an opinion on the effectiveness of the group's internal controls;  
Evaluate whether the accounting policies adopted by the financial management commissioner are appropriate, and whether the accounting estimates and related disclosures made are reasonable;  
Determine whether the financial management commissioner's use of the going concern basis for accounting is appropriate, and based on the audit evidence obtained, determine whether there are significant uncertainties related to events or circumstances that may cast significant doubt on the group's ability to continue as a going concern. If I conclude that there are significant uncertainties, it is necessary to draw the users' attention to the relevant disclosures in the financial statements in the auditor's report. If the relevant disclosures are insufficient, I would issue an auditor's report with a non-unqualified opinion. My conclusion is based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of the auditor's report. However, future events or circumstances may lead to the group's inability to continue as a going concern;  
Evaluate the overall presentation, structure, and content of the financial statements, including disclosures, and whether the financial statements fairly present transactions and events; and  
Obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of entities or business activities within the group in order to express an opinion on the financial statements. I am responsible for directing, supervising, and performing the group audit. I assume full responsibility for my audit opinion.

I will communicate with the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee regarding the audit scope and timeline, major audit findings, and any significant internal control deficiencies identified during the audit period.

I will also submit a statement to the Review Committee under the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's Advisory Committee, explaining that I have complied with the relevant ethical requirements regarding independence, and communicating all relationships and other matters that are reasonably considered to affect my independence, as well as the relevant preventive measures where applicable.

I will determine which matters are most significant for the audit of the current financial statements, thereby forming key audit matters, based on communications with the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee. I will describe these matters in the auditor's report unless laws and regulations prohibit the public disclosure of a particular matter, or in extremely rare circumstances, where the negative consequences that would result from communicating a matter in my report are expected to outweigh the public interest, in which case I will decide not to communicate the matter in the report.
